labels.analysis: The MCP Server functions primarily as a remote shell execution environment, allowing users to run shell commands on a remote system securely. It supports configurable options like custom working directories and timeouts, and integrates with MCP-compatible clients via streaming or standard I/O transports. The primary use case revolves around executing remote shell commands, which aligns with system management and remote command execution.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Operating System" is chosen because the server's core functionality involves managing and executing shell commands on a remote system, which is a fundamental aspect of operating system operations. The secondary label "Security & Authentication" is included due to the server's emphasis on secure remote session management. No custom label is needed as the predefined labels sufficiently cover the server's functionality.

tools.name: shell-exec
tools.description: Execute shell commands remotely. This tool allows running shell commands on the remote system and returns the output. Use with caution as it can execute any command.

server_info_crawled.overview: Execute shell commands remotely with detailed output and configurable options. Manage remote shell sessions securely with support for custom working directories and timeouts. Integrate seamlessly with MCP-compatible clients via SSE or stdio transports.

tools.name: shell-exec
tools.description: Execute shell commands remotely. This tool allows running shell commands on the remote system and returns the output. Use with caution as it can execute any command.

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@samihalawa/remote-shell-terminal-mcp/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
